Description: Terracotta cylindrical fitting. A cylindrical stand, tapering from bottom to top. At the top are mouldings, below which is the head of a young satyr surmounting a vinescroll that rises from a handled bowl. Below the bowl is a head of another young satyr or of a maenad: the workmanship is poor. The object stands on a low moulded plinth with a row of dentils. The back is plain except for mouldings at the top and bottom, the latter including the dentils of the front. Hollow; two-piece mould. Micaceous orange to red-brown Nile silt; traces of a white dressing, mainly on the front, but some in the mouldings at the back.
Curator's comments: BM Terracotta IV Comparanda. Close: Bayer-Niemeier 1988: no. 716, dated second to third century ad; Fischer 1994: no. 1205, dated Hellenistic to early Roman period. Near: Bayer-Niemeier 1988: nos 717 and 718, dated second to third century ad; Weber 1914: no. 268, said to be from the Fayum.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3274)
Condition: The top and the bottom edges are slightly damaged.
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
